Environmental Change Network http://www.ecn.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. A Question of Ecology \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Answers from Biological Recording http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/nfbr-conf-2015 National Forum for Biological Recording conference 2015 \ufffd\ufffd

Note: There is a call for quickfire talks, posters and demonstrations of software and tools

Biodiversity information is crucial to understanding ecological relationships and supporting conservation effort in a changing climate. Use of volunteer-collected biological records by the professional scientific community is widely encouraged and celebrated, but much interpretation of biological records is carried out by amateur naturalists, who are uncovering new ecological knowledge from their own records and sharing that knowledge with others.

Biological recording is not just about producing checklists, dot maps or providing \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbig data\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for others to analyse; it is a way of engaging with the natural world which both raises questions and provides answers to them.

A Question of Ecology will celebrate achievements, highlight opportunities and seek to overcome obstacles regarding the use of biological records to answer ecological questions.

Objectives

The conference aims to:

  • Raise awareness of how biological records can be interpreted to answer ecological questions and lead to conservation action at a site-specific, local, national and international scale.
  • Empower volunteer recorders and their organisations to get more out of their biological records by highlighting effective approaches to data collection and analysis.
  • Foster collaboration between the professional research community and volunteer recording community through examples of good practice.
  • Discuss barriers to the use of biological records for research and start a dialogue between the biological recording and research communities about how to overcome those barriers

\ufffd\ufffd

This NFBR conference is\ufffd\ufffda joint event in collaboration with the British Ecological Society\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Macroecology Special Interest Group.

]]> No publisher admin External event 2015-02-17T09:32:10Z Event Woodland ecology and management workshop http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/woodland-ecol-manag A course run by the Oxford University Department for Continuing Education A 1-day workshop in Woodland Ecology and Management to be held in Wytham Woods, Oxfordshire, by the Oxford University Department for Continuing Education. Aimed at professionals, woodland owners/managers including small woodland owners, students and community groups, it offers a firm intellectual base from which participants can further their engagement in woodland ecology, or implement a woodland management plan. The course is taught via a blend of lectures, discussions, a practical session, and a field visit into Wytham Woods.

Organizer: Jocelyne Hughes, Department of Continuing Education, Oxford University.

There is a fee for this course.

]]> No publisher admin training course External event 2015-01-29T13:49:18Z Event Linking ecological research across Wytham Woods http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/wytham-research-meeting A meeting to bring together ecologists and other forest researchers with research interests in Wytham Woods, Oxfordshire (an ECN site) Wytham Woods has been a leading centre for forest research over the last 60 years. Around 50 ecological research projects are currently running, involving groups from several universities. Collaboration and knowledge-exchange opportunities are clear across this pool of Wytham scientists, yet such relationships can be slow to develop without a forum for collective discussions.

This meeting will address this by bringing together all ecological scientists involved in Wytham research and other forest researchers, to determine how we can best learn from each other\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds work. Talks from Wytham scientists will show the depth and breadth of research undertaken at Wytham, with contributions from early-career researchers. Panel sessions will enable further knowledge-exchange.

The meeting is also open to any forest researchers who are interested in learning more about Wytham, or establishing links for future collaborative work within this network.

Online registration will open shortly, so check the BES Forest Ecology Special Group page for updates:\ufffd\ufffdhttp://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/getting-involved/special-interest-groups/forest-ecology-group/.

]]> No publisher admin External event research 2015-01-29T13:45:00Z Event Perth III: Mountains of Our Future Earth http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/perth-iii An international conference organised by The Centre for Mountain Studies at Perth College, University of the Highlands & Islands, in collaboration with the Mountain Research Initiative (MRI) and the Global Mountain Biodiversity Assessment (GMBA). Note: there is a\ufffd\ufffdcall for abstracts (closing date: 27 February 2015)

The Centre for Mountain Studies, in collaboration with the Mountain Research Initiative (MRI) and the Global Mountain Biodiversity Assessment (GMBA), is organising a third conference \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Perth III \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMountains of Our Future Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. This is a contribution to the global Future Earth programme, a 10-year international research initiative that will develop the knowledge for responding effectively to the risks and opportunities of global environmental change and supporting transformation towards global sustainability in the coming decades.

Mountain areas occupy 24% of the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds land surface; they are home to 12% of the global population, and another 14% of the population live in their immediate proximity. Globally, mountain areas are vital sources of water for agricultural, industrial, and domestic use. They include major centres of biodiversity, often coinciding with centres of cultural diversity where traditional ecological knowledge is maintained. In an urbanising world, mountain areas are key locations for tourism and recreation; some include major urban areas.

Mountain systems are particularly fragile, and subject to both natural and anthropogenic drivers of change. These range from volcanic and seismic events and flooding to global climate change and the loss of vegetation and soils because of inappropriate agricultural and forestry practices and extractive industries. Thus, many mountain ecosystems are moving along trajectories that couple high rates of environmental change with strong economic changes. The collective effect may be to alter the ability of these ecosystems to provide critical goods and services to both mountain and lowland populations. The vital linkages between mountain and lowland systems are increasingly recognised in global and regional policy debates and action. These diverse and inter-related issues have been addressed in two international conferences organised by the Centre for Mountain Studies in Perth, in 2005 and 2010, and provide the context for the 2015 conference.

Involvement of ECN partners & LTER-Europe

Several sessions at the conference are relevant to anyone with an interest in long-term ecosystem research:

  • Advances in observatories of mountain social-ecological systems (Jan Dick, CEH)
  • LTSER sites in European mountain areas (Thomas Spiegelberger, Irstea)
  • Mountain ecosystem services, adaptive management and global change (Maria Nijnik, JHI, with others)
]]> No publisher admin Conference event:featured External event 2014-11-18T16:00:48Z Event LTER-Europe conference & workshops http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/lter-europe-conf-2015 The next LTER-Europe (of which ECN is a member) will be organized as part of a week of events including the final ExpeER Related Sites Group meeting and workshops on infrastructure requirements for European biodiversity research. LTER-Europe is combining several meetings in one conference week, starting 16 February in Vienna. These include:

  • Expert workshop on infrastructure requirements for biodiversity research (Monday 16 Feb)
  • Expert workshop on the integration of in-situ networks in the field of environmental research and monitoring (16-17 Feb)
  • Final Related Sites Group meeting of the ExpeER project, with presentation of key results relevant for sites and national in-situ networks (17-18 Feb)
  • Presentation of the LTER-Austria White Paper (19 Feb, a.m.)
  • LTER-Europe conference (19-20 Feb)

\ufffd\ufffd

For details and updates, refer to the LTER-Europe website.

]]> No publisher admin Conference External event 2014-11-13T11:35:00Z Event Protecting Scotland\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Biodiversity: Monitoring in action http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/scotlands-biodiv-monitoring A meeting to consider the importance of monitoring for delivering key conservation policy challenges A joint event organised by the Science and Technical group for the Scottish Biodiversity Strategy, BES, and CIEEM. The meeting will consider the importance of monitoring for delivering the 2020 Challenge for Scotland\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Biodiversity (and other conservation policy), and will explore who uses monitoring data, how monitoring can make a difference on the ground for conservation, and new approaches to and challenges for monitoring.

]]> No publisher admin Conference External event Workshop 2014-09-19T13:35:22Z Event \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdValuing our Life Support Systems\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd natural capital summit http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/nci-valuing-our-life-support-systems-2014 The second \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdValuing our Life Support Systems\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd natural capital summit, hosted by the Natural Capital Initiative The summit will:

    1. Derive a common understanding of what natural capital really means
    2. Understand in plain language the natural and social science behind it
    3. Find and demonstrate ways in which sectors and initiatives can work, and are working, together to apply it
    4. Identify ways of ensuring that practical responses have scientific rigour
    5. Communicate recommendations for ways forward across the sectors.

This summit is for:

Academics \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd wanting to maximise the impact of their research in this area, and to identify new research priorities

Policy makers \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd wanting to develop policies that enable better accounting for our natural capital in government and business activity

Business \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd particularly businesses whose risks and products are particularly dependent on natural resources and systems

Civil Society \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for charities that work to protect natural resources and promote better care for our natural environment

Event organised by the Natural Capital Initiative, whose partners include CEH and JHI (also ECN partners). For event details, see the link below.

]]> No publisher admin ecosystem services External event natural capital event:featured 2014-08-04T07:45:00Z Event Grassland Ecology and Management http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/grassland-ecology-management University of Oxford Short Course This session will provide students will an overview of grassland types in the UK, their importance and ecology. The session will be hosted at a key lowland grassland reserve and led by the previous manager of the site Dr Kerry Lock.

Students will be led through the armoury of grassland techniques available to managers and the evidence-base behind them. This will provide a useful platform for discussing key issues affecting the achievement of management goals in grassland management and how variations in the use of management techniques can impact species composition of grassland.

This one day course is to be delivered by Dr Kerry Lock, and held from 10am-5pm at Chimney Meadows nature reserve.

Cost: \ufffd\ufffd125

]]> No publisher admin training course External event 2014-03-28T11:49:51Z Event Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as a tool for Environmental Management http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/GIS-course University of Oxford Short Course Geographic Information System (GIS) is becoming a vital tool in Conservation and Enviornmental Management. GIS permits the digital mapping of species locations, transect routes, reserve boundaries, features (such as ponds) and reserve management (such as coppiced areas). NGOs are using digital programmes to develop and link with GIS, as a vital component of more robust methods of planning management and recording. This session will assume no prior knowledge of GIS and introduce students to the basics, utilising Phase 1 data to enable students to gain first-hand experience, under the watchful eye of the tutor who has 30 years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experience in GIS mapping.

This one day workshop will be delivered by Mr Chris Talbot, and will run from 10am-5pm at Ewert House, Summertown, Oxford.

Cost: \ufffd\ufffd125

]]> No publisher admin training course External event 2014-03-28T11:35:00Z Event Woodland Ecology and Management http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/woodland-ecology-management University of Oxford short course Experts Dr Keith Kirby (previously advisor to Natural England) and Mr Nigel Fisher (conservator of Wytham Woods) will lead students on a journey through the essentials of Woodland Ecology and onto the vital woodland management techniques available to maintain these magnificent habitats. Wytham Woods are an area of ancient semi-natural woodland, owned by the University of Oxford and used for environmental research (including for ECN monitoring). The site has an exceptionally rich flora and fauna, and a wealth of long term biological data.

Cost: \ufffd\ufffd125

(Please note this event is not organised by ECN)

]]> No publisher admin training course External event 2014-03-28T11:15:00Z Event Field Techniques for Surveying Invertebrates http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/invertebrate-surveying University of Oxford short course This online distance learning course offers expert-led training in invertebrate surveying techniques from planning and preparations through to sampling strategies, surveying methods and reporting. Topics covered include interception and responsive trapping techniques, identification and taxonomic considerations, habitat description and evaluation, managing specimens, and analysing and interpreting data.

Cost: \ufffd\ufffd295

]]> No publisher admin training course External event 2014-03-28T11:15:00Z Event BES special interest group on climate change: inaugural meeting http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/bes-cc-sig-launch First meeting of a new special interest group The British Ecological Society is launching a new special interest group on climate change and we are organising a one day conference on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdEcological impacts of climate change: building on the IPCC fifth assessment report\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd on 25 April at Charles Darwin House in London.

Speakers will include some of the authors of the forthcoming IPCC report on Climate Change Impacts and Adaptation (Working Group 2), which is due at the of March, as well as other leading ecologists working in the field.

The provisional programme and a link to the booking site are now available on the BES website.

http://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/getting-involved/special-interest-groups/climate-change-ecology/

Places are limited so book early to guarantee your place.

]]> No publisher admin Conference climate change External event 2014-03-17T14:25:00Z Event 2013 UKEAP Biennial Stakeholder and Local Site Operator Meeting http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/ukeap-stakeholder-lso-meeting Biennial meeting run by the UK Eutrophying and Acidifying atmospheric Pollutants (UKEAP) network, for stakeholders and Local Site Operators. The 2013 biennial Stakeholder and Local Site operator meeting for the Defra UK Eutrophying and Acidifying Atmospheric pollutants (UKEAP) project will take place at CEH Lancaster on Thursday 10th \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Friday 11th October. UKEAP very much value Stakeholder and LSO input and hope that you can take part in this meeting. It will be an important opportunity to receive feedback and there will be plenty of opportunity for discussion regarding rural air quality monitoring in the UK.\ufffd\ufffd Note, spaces at this event are limited on a first come first serve basis. If you would like to attend the meeting and have not had an invite, please contact UKEAP (ukeap@ceh.ac.uk).

]]> No publisher admin External event 2013-09-06T09:24:42Z Event Science for the environment conference: Mapping knowledge needs for future horizons http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/dce-conference-2013 Identifying knowledge gaps for the Climate Action and Resource Efficiency Challenge in Horizon 2020 Horizon2020 is the European Commission\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, covering the period 2014-2020. One of the aims of the programme is to promote scientific research that tackles the grand societal challenges facing Europe and the World. This conference is an opportunity to gain insight and impact on which scientific needs that are going to be addressed in Horizon2020.

Horizon 2020 points to six major societal challenges to which the research community should identify solutions. One of these is the challenge: Climate action, resource efficiency and raw materials. The societal challenges part of Horizon 2020 should increase the effectiveness of research and innovation using a challenge-based approach, bringing together resources and knowledge across different fields, technologies and disciplines, including social sciences and humanities research.

Aarhus University and the Partnership for European Environmental Research (PEER) will by this conference, bring research activities together across disciplines to foster solutions to the challenges facing society. Fifteen years after the UN Aarhus Convention was agreed in Aarhus, we will involve the scientific community in a transparent and evidence-based\ufffd\ufffd process to inform and inspire the European strategic research agenda, in support of a green and prosperous future for Europe and the World. The conference will include facilitated topical workshops, where proposals will be formed for future research needs in an open process.

We therefore invite researchers to Aarhus University on the October 2-4, 2013 to take stock of and assess the scientific progress towards tackling the grand environmental challenges. And to apply the outcome to provide input to the European Commission on the knowledge gaps and future research needs in Horizon 2020.

The Partnership for European Environmental Research (PEER), of which DCE/Aarhus University is a member, will take the collected advice of the conference to the Commission and communicate the views of the research community to DG Research in November 2013, to incorporate these in\ufffd\ufffd the process of developing and improving the strategic research agenda of Horizon 2020.

Main themes

  • Climate action
    • mitigation and adaptation
  • Resource efficiency
    • natural resources, ecosystems, raw materials
  • Green economy
    • eco-innovation
]]> No publisher admin Conference External event research 2013-09-04T14:08:50Z Event Training courses: Integrated Spatial Modelling of Ecosystem Services http://www.ecn.ac.uk/events/training-invest-courses One-day introductory course and week-long intensive course covering InVEST software, a family of tools designed by the Natural Capital Project which helps users to map and value the goods and services from nature that are essential for sustaining and fulfilling human life. *** Course registration closes 31st July 2013 ***
  • Does your organisation aim to map and value the goods and services from nature?
  • Would tools to assess the tradeoffs associated with alternative land use choices be useful?
  • Do you want to develop your skills and knowledge in the state-of-the-art of this research field?


    • If so the following courses may be relevant:

    • A one-day (14th Oct) 'Introduction to InVEST' workshop- for researchers and practitioners who wish to gain a basic working knowledge of InVEST software
    • A week-long intensive training course (14th-18th Oct)- for users who seek in-depth understanding of the InVEST models and to consider their future development


    For course programme and application details follow the link below.

    Course registration closes 31st July 2013.
